column4: how do you determine what user groups a process is running under?
*takes a look*
er, id
ps --group blah

no, I want to find the list of all the groups a process is running within.  For example, when I run 'id' as a user, I get a list of groups that I am a member of.  I would like to see that list for a given process.
ps -eo %G%c   # %c shows command,  %G show group name
so  ps -eo %G%c|grep "command_name"  show get what you want
for details, see  "man  ps"
There should be a long list of groups, though, not a single group.
what do you mean... each process can only run by a SINGLE user & his primary group
Oh interesting; what if there's a permission from a secondary group that the process needs?
why would it need that.  is it file permisison that you are asking
yup
file permission depends on the file it is accessing.  as far as i know, the process can access whatever the user has permission to
that includes all the groups the user belong to
so the process has access to all the groups the user belongs to - at the point in time that the process is created, correct?  So how would I get that list?
run command "groups" as the user who run that process
that only tells me what groups the user has from the point in time that that shell was started - not the same thing.
what you want to do actually

I'm curious if it's possible to determine what those memberships are for the process, rather than looking at what is /now/ the memberships.
